qas.question: What caused the unsurface of the Grecian monotony in politics?
When did the nation not reestablish itself?

qas.question: What was bolstered by the the first downward spiral of the Empire of Trebizond?
Which factoring war wasn't ongoing in 1828 and shares the of a previous scuttle?

context: A distinct Greek political identity re-emerged in the 11th century in educated circles and became more forceful after <a0_0>the <b5_0>fall of Constantinople to the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade in 1204<b5_0/><a0_0/>, so that when the <a1_0>empire was revived in <b6_0>1261<b6_0/><a1_0/>, it became in many ways a Greek national state. That new notion of nationhood engendered a deep interest in the classical past culminating in the ideas of the Neoplatonist <a2_0>philosopher <b7_0>Gemistus Pletho, who abandoned Christianity<b7_0/>.<a2_0/> However, it was the combination of Orthodox Christianity with a specifically Greek identity that shaped the Greeks' notion of themselves in the empire's twilight years. The <a3_0><b8_0>interest in the Classical Greek heritage<b8_0/> was complemented by a renewed emphasis on Greek Orthodox identity<a3_0/>, which was reinforced in the late Medieval and Ottoman Greeks' links with their fellow Orthodox Christians in the Russian Empire. These were further strengthened following the fall of the Empire of Trebizond in 1461, after which and until the <a4_0><b9_0>second Russo-Turkish War<b9_0/><a4_0/> of 1828-29 hundreds of thousands of Pontic Greeks fled or migrated from the Pontic Alps and Armenian Highlands to southern Russia and the Russian South Caucasus (see also Greeks in Russia, Greeks in Armenia, Greeks in Georgia, and Caucasian Greeks).
